Now I close with much love and 10000000 kisses from mamma, Ed and yours, lovingly, Annie.
Geneva, 19th. of October. Wednesday.
Dear baby,
I can hardly snatch a few seconds
time to write this to you and to
thanks you for the money I received this
morning. My der boy, there was
really no hurry about sending it,
you know that I could have waited
every well - I am a great capitalist 
you know and don't hanleer?
after the money at all. Nevertheless
I thank you for sending it. My

savings are flying like anything now
- I have to buy books, painting utensils,
etc. which cost like fury anf by
Christmas time I will just have a few
misy franks left. It makes me mad!
I have so much to work now 
that I hardly know "where the head
stands me". I guess I have to do almost
as much as you do. You know
I take two music-lessons, then I go
to Miss Testuz one morning and the
three other forenoons from 9-12 I 
spend at the atelier of "professor
Wathins", my new painting-teacher.
Then I have begun to take Italian
lessons (two a week) and,

as you know, I have two hours of
French every afternoon. Besides, we 
have now engaged a young girl to
come three evenings of the week and
talk French with us. If you count
the lessons I have to work, my practicing,
etc. all in, you will see that I 
am quite busy. Please excuse this
detailed account, I did not mean
to bore you with it.
Received the book of "Americanisms"
and the clippings about that "Distanz
Ritt" this morning. Both interested
us very much and we thank you
for them.
Please send one of Papa's good

books Rnifnbuinfn? to Mrs. Hesing. Her
address is : "Alster Pension, Alsterdamm
5, Hamburg."
Last Sunday, Mrs. Powell, Ed and 
I went up the Rocher du Naye and
enjoyed it very much; the weather
was middling fair.
I sm taking painting lessons together
with Mr. and Mrs. von Löper now, 
in oil! I copy bautiful landscapes
and feel like a regular artist: Wait
till you see!
Please excuse this horrible letter,
I just squeezed it in between two
lessons. - Everybody (even mrs.
Powell and the Consul) send their regards.

Geneva, Sunday, 20/ Nove 1892.
Dearest Baby!
It is an age ago since I wrote
you a letter and you must think
that I am either dead, lazy or
that I have not got the money to
pay a postage-stamp. But it is 
neither of these reasons. I simply
have so much to do that I hardly
know "where the head stands me."
Sunday is the only day on which
I have no lesson, but then I have
to practise, sew, mend and write
letters. I am always very glad

for your Sunday letters and very sorry
to-day that we are not going to
have one from you this time. Formerly
we used to get them every Tuesday
morning, but the last few times they
did not come until Wednesday.
How is that? ----- Mamma wrote
you that I am always croaking now,
which is hardly true. Only, I eat as
much as ever and I have not the time
to go out walking to digest it every
day, so I grow fatter and fatter and
begin to croak. If I were very aesthetic,
I would say it is "over-study."
Now I want to tell you about a
great fix that we are in. This morning
I received a letter from Nanny

in which she tells us quite coolly
that she will come down here for
a few weeks and (as you told her that
we are going to Nizza) she will go
there with us too. Of course we don't 
want her (if we can help it) for several
reasons. So I guess I will write her
that mamma is very sick and that
we did not let you know about it
so as not to frighten you. That will
explain anything you may have told
them about our being healthy and
enjoying ourselves. If Nanny tells you
anything about mamma's sickness
you need not be frightened, but please
play your rôle well and pretend
that you are. If you can, please help
us a little, in trying to persuadeN?

not to come here. But be careful about
it! - Did you understand all
this? - - - My Italian and painting
are getting on beautifully, especially
the latter. I have finished my fourth
"opus" yesterday, the gallery consists
of 2 landscapes and 2 figures now, all
in oil, the largest about 12x15. I 
should like to sell them for about 1
franc a square inch. - What about
Christmas? I think I shall paint a
tambourin for mamma (extra fine)
and work one or two little things.
How is your drawing (that nice large
one) getting on?
Mamma wats me to tell you
that you ought to call on Schwendy's
some time: they are expecting your
and you will like it, I guess.

Genève, Nov. 24th 1892.
Thrusday.
Dear Baby.
I have such a miserable
pen that you may thank your
stars if you are able to make
out this letter.
I want to write to you
on general principle", but I
have one or two special reasons
too. One is that I want
to ask you a favour.
At the beginning, upside down:
And all well, hope you are
Can you read this letter?

Nanny's birthday comes around
next Monday (29th of 
November), so, if you can, please
go there to congratulate her. It 
is not necessary to go exactly
on Monday, Sunday will do
just as well. Take her some
nice candy for about 6 or 7 Mark,
that would be best. --- I wrote
her that our stay here would
be indefinite and that we
probably would not go to Nice
at all. (All to "schreck her off"

from coming here). You had
better keep up that idea, saying
that I had mentioned it to you,
to your great surprise.
To-day is Thanksgiving
and we are going to have a 
turkey together with Mrs.
Powells. Mr. (confound this pen!)
Mr. Vultier wiill roast it for us,
so I think it will be good. Poor
little boy! Aren't you going
to have any Thanksgiving?
- We must begin to

think about Christmas already.
I know of three things that
mamma would like to to have.
1. A large silver spoon for her
collection (I am afraid we can't
have the beautiful one, we 
invented together, made; so we shall
have to buy a very fine one ready
made, don't you think so?)
2. A little emaille plate like 
you see them in the shops here.
3. A little ivory carving.
We must think this over
a little. Stop for to-day, in
a great hurry. 10000 kisses,
Anna

Geneva, 16 th. of Dec. 1892.
Dear Walt,
Just came home with Ed
from buying mamma's Christmas
presents. Jimminy? Crackers!
How much do you think we 
spent? 43 Franles?.
And what did we get for it?
Two misy little packages,
about 2x4 inches large.
Now I suppose you want
to know what is in them?

If you want to send money for mamma's presents (If you don't want to, you don't need to) then please do not send so much!!

Hope you can read my writing.
Are you well? Have not heard from you since Tuesday.

One is a little bronze thing, 
like this: two hares -- image These are two
hares, a big one and a litlle
one. The big one is holding
the little one up by the ears and
hitting him with a stick. Isn't
the drawing beautiful? - This
bronze cost 13 Franks.
No. 2 is a silver paper knife
Very fine and solid, not too
large (about four inches long),
in a fine plush box. This 
costs - horribile dictu! -
30 Franks.

What do you think of this? I
hope you are satisfied with what
we bought; it is just what
mamma wished for.
Eddie can only give about
15 or 20 Franks in all. You
know he is dead broke this
year.
I can give from 35 to 40:
that is all, for my money
has been flying like fury here.
I have always had to buy books
and paint and brushes, etc.
I have painted mamma
a pretty "Schreibmappe" on wood.

It is an "oil - landscape."
Besides I am going to give her
all the paintings I have done in
my lessons (which she has not 
seen yet), about 4 in all.
I am sorry I can only 
talk business to you to-day,
but really, I have not a minute's
time for another word.
Though I regret awfully not to
have you here Christmas, I am
glad that you are going to
Junge's: you will have a nice
time there. --- Regards to and
from all. With kisses, Annie.

Geneva, 17th. of Dec. 1892.
Dear Walt,
I write this in mamma's
name to tell you that you
need not buy anything for
uncle Ernst. Mamma has bought
the following things for the Junge 
family: silver spoon, sugar-tong
and fork for aunt Sophie; silver 
scissors for Else; and a silver
pencil for uncle Ernst. That
will do, I think; only, of course,
you must get something for 
Rudi yet. You will know best
what to buy for him: let it be
about 15 mark, or something
like taht. - - - All these
silver things are going to be 
sent to your address on Tuesday,
so you will get them about
Friday. You can then take them 
over to Junge's on Saturday.
Hope you are well and will
enjoy your Christmas. Love from
all. Kisses, Annie.

Geneva, 18 th. of Dec. 1892.
Dear baby,
Just received your money;
but, my dear little boy,
it is by far too much! I 
don't like to spend all tht
for mamma, because Eddy
and I can only give much
less. I am sure, too, that
mamma does not want
you to "knapps" off your 
pocket-money to buy her
presents; she will not like
that.
I thank you very much,
meanwhile, for sending
the money. Will try to
buy something nice for it, 
but do not mean to spend
it all.
With kisses,
Annie.

Geneva, Dec. 30th. 1892.
Dear baby!
I guess this is about
the last letter I shall
write to you from Geneva, 
as to-day is
Friday and we leave
here Tuesday morning
at 6 30.
We received your postal
this morning and are
glad that you have
got the box at last.
I hope that the things

in it were still fresh
enough to taste well.
Dr. Jobst wrote to mamma
that you get a 
glass of "Ungarwein" every
morning, to strengthen
you. Now mamma is
very anxious, of course,
and wanys to know
whether you are sick, or
weak, or whether any
thing is a matter with
you. You had better reassure
her on this subject
as soon as possible.
Now I am going to 
put down our traveling
route for you:

Leave Geneva - Tuesday a.m.
pass Torino - to Genoa.
Leave Genoa - Friday, a.m.
pass Ventimiglia - to Mentone.
Leave Mentone - Saturday 
to Monte Carlo.
Leave Monte Carlo - Monday 
arrive at Nizza.
At Nizza (having arrived
there Monday, 9 th. of Jannary)
we shall stay about
a week and then go on
to Paris.
If we should happen
to change this plan on 
the way, we shall telegraph.
So don't be 
frightened if you receive

a wire message. Letters 
you may send to Eddie;
only your Sunday letter
(8 th of January) wll be reach
us "poste restante, Nice".
Please do not forget
to congratulate Anna
Thuernler? to her birthday,
2 nd. of January.
Mamma wants you to 
go to Schwendy's driving
vacation: please do so.
Mamma tells me to
tell you that you are to
buy some sausage and
meat for yourself, as perhaps
you do not get enough
to eat at Jobst's.
Happy New - Year!
Kisses, Annie

Dearest baby,
Received your letter
(with inclosed letters) last
night,upon our arrival here in
Dessau. Everything is all right.
Please do not forget that we
must have a receipt for the
picture from Fargo & Wells. Did
they not send it to you yet?
If you have time, would you
go to Lilly Meyers about my
album? It is not at all necessary
though, of course.
Mamma says you need not
go to Weimar, but may come
here as soon as you have done 
with business, lessons and
calls. That will be Sunday or
Monday, I suppose. Much love
from us all and kisses from yours,
Anna.
(Regards to all).
If you come on Sunday, we can go to the theatre in the evening.

not sleep nights at all,
because she thought you
were half dead already;
now she is a little relieved.

I want to tell you that in your
birthday letter to mamma none 
of us could read the short-hand,
because Ed and I had both forgotten
the little we have ever
known and we were surprised
to see that you still remembered
so much of it. The

Mamma read about the cholera

HÔTELS SCHWEIZERHOF & LUZERNERHOF
LUCERNE
Interlaken, August 18 th. 
Thursday.
Dear Baby.
How are you, little boy? I hope
you are well as we are. That 
is, I cannot say that I am
quite well, being forced to use
a great deal of "Oval King", in
consequence of eating fruit, milk
and beer all to-gether. Well, it
is not of importance.
Eddy wrote to you from Schaffhausen, 
so I will tell you about
our journey from there here. First
we went to Zürich, a very beautiful
town, where we only staid one
night. Then, on Sunday, we came
Thousand kisses and much love from us all there. Your loving sister Anna.
laken, we are staying. "Hôtel Jungfrau".

to Lucerne and staid there until
this morning (Thrusday). I supposse
it will surprise you very much
to hear that since we are in Switzerland
(including Schaffhausen,
Zürich, Lucerne and this place) we
have had the most beautifiul weather
imaginable, not a drop of rain
or a cloud, clear views all the 
time, just like in Italy two years 
ago. Only it is unbearably hot,
we are almost drowned in perspiration
and flop around like sick
flies; it must be over 100 degrees.
I hope it is not as bad as that
in Berlin. Don't you wish we
would have had such clear weather
here in 1890 with papa? He would
have liked it and you too, my
little baby, would have had a 
better idea of Switzerland. Well, you
may see it again some time and
then I hope it will not be so hot.
You know unclear letter will reach us for the coming week. Here, at Interlaken, we are staying:

In Lucerne we went up the Rigi
(nice view); took a trip around
the lake and stopped for dinner
at Flüelen just as we did with
papa and you; we even had the 
same seats at the table d'hôte in
Flüelen, where we met Herrn von
Avignon. Do you remember? Then
we took Ed to the Gletscher-garten,
the lion and the old bridge.
One afternoon we took tea at Villa
Tribschen with Minnie Hanck and
her husband; it was very pleasant.
By the way, she is not coming
to Berlin until December, but
then you can go to see her.
Now, we have arrived here
at Interlaken a little while ago
and shall probably stay until
Sunday. Then we go to Berne
(where we will find your dear
letter), spend a day there and go
to Geneve to meet Pietsch's on the

so much for mamma's presents. I could have waited. Many thanks!

24 th. At least, we hope they will

Looking out of my window just
now, I can see the "Jungfrau" right
in front of me (that is, about
twelve miles off), perfectly white
and looking beautiful against the
blue sky with green mountains in
the foreground. To-morrow we
are going on an excursion to the
"Grindelwald" which is still nearer
the "Jungfrau". If I find a pretty
view, I will send you it.
Your nice letter to Ed was
a great joy for us, we were glad
to hear that you are well and
enjoying yourself. I am glad Mr.
Rothbarth came to see you and hope
he will invite you to a nice dinner.
Are you hard up with money,
little boy? Just ask Dr. Jobst for some
if you need any; don't use up all your

pocket-money. By the way, it was not necessary to pay me back

VUE DU JARDIN DE L'HÔTEL
Hôtel Baur au Lac, Zurich
August 14 th; 1892.
Dear Walt,
Arrived here last
night and shall stay until
four o'clock this afternoon,
when we leave for 
Lucerne. That is only two
hours from here. Weather
is beautiful, hope it will
be so at Lucerne too. We
are all pretty well. Shall
write you a letter from
Lucerne. Much love from 
us all.
Annie.

Wednesday, 90. M.
August 10 th, 1892.
Konstanz.
My dear baby
This morning at eight
o'clock we left Nuremberg
and took the train
for Friedrichshafen (Bodensee),
where we arrived
at five o'clock in the
afternoon. There we waited
an hour and then crossed
the lake on a steamer, 
from Friedrichshafen to
Konstanz, where we have 
just arrived. It is raining
badly, so the ride over

the lake was not as
beautiful as it might have
been; still we saw that
the seenery is very fine
here and Ed is not at all
disappointed by the Alps
as we were (you and I
two years ago, I mean).
We thought of you and
Papa all day to-day
and semembered all
you had told us about
the Bodensee and Konstanz.
We are staying at the
"Insel-Hôtel" here, which
is very grand and stylish
and crowded with Eng-

lishmen and Americans.
We shall look at the
"unclear" to-morrow
and then go right on to
Schaffhansen to see the 
"Rheinfall". We shall
spend one night there
and then go to "Zürich"
on the 12 th. Friday.
There we shall only
stop a day and then go
to Lucerne. Mamma
wants me to tell you
that letters will reach
us "Poste Restante", Lucerne
until the 17 th. of Aug.

both are due to circumstances.

and much love from
mamma, Ed, and yours,
Annie.

Elgersburg, July 26 th., 1892
Dear little baby-boy,
How are you? I hope you are
all right and have become
accustomed to your studies
again. Sunday night mamma
dreamt that you were calling
her and when she looked at
her watch it was just half
past ten, the time you were
on the train. Of course mamma
supposed that about 65

different disasters had happened
to you and so I telegraphhed.
Dr. Jobst must have thought
we were crazy to make the
telegraph-wires work for our
special pleasure all day long.
Last night I suppose you
met Ed and did those errands
with him. I wonder whether
the photographs can be finished
in time and whether I shall
be able to have my painting
done by the eightth Well, we
shall see!
Since you left, we have
the most beautiful weather
here, sunshine and clear
blue sky. It's a shame!

Why couldn't it be so nice last week while you were here?
I am stydying Italian with great zeal, so as to reach lesson 75 soon. I am not getting on very fast, though, as I write out the translations now.
The "unclear" has not shown up again, which is abominable, the season will be over soon and we must make the best of it whole it lasts. If I were you, I would invest about 20 Pfennigs in cherries every day.

Perhaps we shall go to Ilmenau this afternoon to buy a birthday card for Frida, because mamma thinks I had better not send her my beautiful painting anyway. 
Just this minute we received your postal. I am glad that you had one more day vacation and that you spent it with Ed. I supposed shall receive a package then, either to-day or to-morrow.
Mamma has a head-ache, but otherwise she feels as usual, my Drüse is much better. Many kisses & lots of love to your from mamma and,
yours Anna.

Elgersburg July 76
Dear baby,
Mamma has just telegraphed Eddy to come here, because I am sick in bed with the "unclear" and she does not like to be here alone with me. You know how excited she always gots. 
You need not be the least bit alarmed about my sickness, baby, because the doctor says it is

not at all dangerous only disagreeable. I hope it will be better soon, I am getting tired of fussing around with that ever-lasting "unclear". 
I am writing this letter to inform you of Ed's coming here, so that you will not go to his house Sunday afternoon & then be frightened by finding him gone away. I don't know with what train Ed will come; probably on Sunday afternoon some time night, We just received all

the letters we wrote to Ed and the one you sent him (mamma's) back from Brasch & Rothenstein. There must be a terrible fuss there, I wonder why they always get things so mixed up there?
Mamma wants me to tell you, that if you go to on Sundays or so, you should do so as much as possible with Jobst's. It is better than bumming with Ed.
I would write more, but it is rather incon-

venient to do so in bed, so I had better stop.
Mamma is quite well and (as I told you before) you need not be a bit alarmed about me. I'll be well again soon.
Lots of love to you from mamma & myself.
Your sister
Anna.
Please excuse lead pencil and bad writing!

Elgersburg, Juillet 12, 1892.
Mon chèr Petit!
Maman et moi, nous étions bien étomées quand nous avons reçu votre jolie lettre française ce matin. 
Nous nous rejouisons du progrès que vous faites en francais et, surtout, de la diligence que vous montrez en écrivant aussitôt une telle letter . Bravo, Petit, bravo!
Vous rappelez-vous encore

de ce que M. Barry disait toujours? "Le petit Walter deviendra quelque jour un grand homme!". Je crois bien qu'il aura raison maintenent.
Comme vous voyez nous avons quitté Kissingen. Depuis lundi nous sommes ici à Elgersburg, où maman faut prendre des bains froids et de massage pour les nerves. Il nous faut rester ici pour trois ou quatre semaines. C'est un tant petit village, pas plus d'un hôtel et pas de magazins. C'est bien ennuyeux! Maman est occupée tout le jour en prenant des bains, d'électricité, de massage et des cataplasmes.
J'éspère que c'est bon pour elle!

Avez-vous reçu les bâtons en boutons d'ivoire, que nous vous avons envoyés de Kissingen?
Veuillez nous le faire savoir aussitôt que possible, parceque nous ne voulons pas perdre ces bâtons. (Cette dernière phrase est d'un style tout à fait incorrect).
Depuis quelques jours il y avait beaucoup de confusion regardant les lettres d'Eddy. 
Toutes les lettres que nous lui avons ecrites à son adresse: "Hardenbergstr. 24", sont étées retournées par Brasch & Rothenstein. Alors, il n'a pas reçu de nos lettres depuis longtemps et il ne sait rien de nous.

Je me rappelle bien du difficile discours entre Caesar et Ariovist dans Caesar. Ce sont des horribles châpitres et j'éspère que vous les finirez bientôt. C'est brillant que vous avez eu la meilleure composition cette fois.
Mon français n'est pas aussi bien que le votre, c'est sure, et j'ai peur que vous ne pouvez pas le lire. Je vous écrirai bientôt une autre lettre en anglais ou en allemand, cela va mieux.
Mamman et moi, nous sommes bien.
Beaucoup de salutations pour vous, chéri, de la part de maman et de ma part. Anna.

Kissingen, July 5 th., 1892.
Dear baby,
I received your nice "painting" yesterday and must tell you, that you really write very good letters. There was a mistake or two in it and a little awkwardness of style yet, but that is not important, so I must repeat my praise and tell you that you write very well. - My

time. A "unclear mit unclear" is terrible, but that music-piece, nr. 15, must have been very nice.
What is that awful hard chapter in Caesar: the building of the Rhine bridge, or indirect discourse? Your studies seem to be progressing well.
What did you do on the 4 th. of July? The Americans here had a banquet (to which I did not go, though they invited me very much) and everybody (I mean, of the Americans) wore red, white and blue bouquets and ribbons.
I saw Bismarck yesterday. He looks very well and stately, but a little old. I am

gland is better already and I think, if I use the Kur about a week longer, it will disappear altogether. - Mamma is feeling as usual, neither sick nor well.
About Hesse-Wartegg's article you are right: he writes very well. He is not here now, but he came to see his wife, who is here, about two weeks ago, and stayed a few days. He is very jolly and a perfect "unclear". You would like him. Just keep that article of his, we do not need it.
I am glad to hear that you went out "kneiping" with Jobst's twice and had a good

going to try and speak with him, which is very easy: you just step up to him and give him a bouquet, when he is taking a walk. Then he has got to say: "thanks", at least.
Oh, by the way, do you know that Mackie Macdonald is married since a few months? Brother Paul wrote it. That is all the news from home. - You need not answer this letter until next Sunday, of course. My handwriting is worse than ever to-day.; shall try to do better next time. Much love, Annie

Kissingen, June 28 th., 1892.
Tuesday.
Dear little Pti,
We received your letter yesterday and were very glad to get it. Now I must tell you about my "Druese", because I suppose you won't see Ed before next Sunday, who could tell you about it. It is not the p v p number pi s? anyway, but a swollen, hardened gland (unclear). When the old Geheimrath here had treated it for about a week and it wouldn't get any

better, mamma was frightened and the doctor (to satisfy her) sent us to Würzbürg to consult a professor. We went there last Sunday and the professor said I should go back to Kissingen and use the baths for two or three weeks. If it is not better then, I must have the gland cut out. Well, I hope it will not come to that, but will go away by itself.
Now I have told you enough about my "Druese".
On what subject did you have to write a composition? Was it hard and did you do it well? If you have only this one composition in a whole year, I guess

that isn't too much and
you will love through it.

Kissingen, June 14 th., 1892.
Dear little Malchen!
unclear The watchmaker said it was a mistake, of course, and all that. He is going to put the right number of glasses in the setting and will then send you the spectacles; you will probably receive them

to-morrow, Wednesday. By the way, that man said that the glasses were beautifully and carefully packed. What a compliment for you!
Poor little baby-Pti, it must be hard for you to get back to the pension from your vacation and I hope you will get accustomed to it soon. Let Eddie take good care of you on Sundays and holidays.
Your letter was very nice this time, like always. Especially the painting was good, but so were the

contents. You really write a pretty style and say a good deal in your letter. (You will think by this epistle that I do not). - I hope your visit at Smirnoff's last Sunday went off smoothly and you had a good dinner there.
Mamma is as well as usual and is making friends with lots of nice people; I am glad that she takes any interest in that.
Mrs. Pfeil sent me a nice pocket-book of tortoise-shell, inlaid with silver, for a present, which is very good

Kissingen, 28 th. of Marz, 1892.
My dearest baby,
We were very glad to find a letter from you here when we arrived day before yesterday. And such a nice letter too! Your style is very pretty, my dear, and even humorous now and then. You were very diligent, too, to have written such a long letter. Nine pages! I almost fell from my chair, when I saw the length of your work. But, child, it

really is not necessary for you to make such exertions and to spend all your recreation-time in writing us letters. You have enough to do already with Greek and Latin and mathematics. We shall be satisfied to hear that you are well, but - if you want to, we cannot prevent you from writing a little more. Now permit me to tell you of two mistakes you had in your letter: "bill-of-fare" is written this way and not "fair". "Translate" is spelled like this, and not (as you had it) "transalate". That is all; everything else was perfect. Your young man who knows Ed Leicht interests me very

much and I shall write to Angelina about him. - I am glad to hear you have such good meals and hope they will agree with you; have you had your stomach-ache again? I am a little disappointed about the "Urania-posts" for I had thought they would be something extraordinary; by your description they only seem to be a "higher" kind of "unclear". But very pretty, I suppose.
I have not written anything about ourselves yet and shall not do so to-day at all; for you will probably receive this letter Sunday morning and when you go to see Ed

in the afternoon he can show you the letter which I have just written to him and which contains all there is to say about us, though that is little enough.
To reassure you about mamma's health, I will tell you that she is as well as usual again and has commenced her "Kur" this morning at half past six, sharp.
Mrs. Hansen's birthday is on the 18 th. of June & you must write to her in time. Address her "unclear" and "unclear". Mamma will send her 100 M. 
Now good-by for to-day, my dear Pti. Much love from mamma and myself to you and Ed. Yours, Annie.

Dear baby, Vienna, May 31 st. Sunday.
Mamma and I just emptied a whole bottle of Hungarian wine to-gether for supper and consequently mamma is trying to laugh herself to pieces, while my letters in this note are dancing a cancan. Vienna is still all right, and we are only awfully sorry that you are not here with us. It would be fine to have you. - - Please mail letters to Hotel Imperial, Vienna until Friday; we shall start off here on a steamer Friday morning, float down the Danube to Budapesth, where we'll arrive in the evening. Saturday we'll telegraph our new address to you from Pesth. - - Don't know exactly what I've written just now, on account of my "Schwips", but guess it's all right. With love, yours Annie.

Vienna, May 29.
Dear baby,
That package with the eardrums has arrived here, but cannot be delivered to us because it is a surgical instrument: - laws of Austria. So the most convenient thing to do, is to return the package to you by mail and ask you to keep it until our return to Berlin. Both o.k. The "Bumkala" very fine. With love, Annie

Thursday, June 4 th.
Dear baby,
I suppose you are having great trouble trying to find a new room: please send us your new address as soon as you can. I would ask you several questions, but you'll probably have no time to answer them this week, - so let it go.
We start here for Budapest to-morrow morning and will arrive there in the evening. After we've telegraphed you our address, please forward our mail to Pesth, but not later than Tuesday. That is, we leave there on Wednesday,probably in the morning. Both o.k. - hope you are, too.
With love, also from mamma, yours Annie.

My dear baby, - Vienna, - Thursday, May 28 th.
Just received your postal and those 3 letters. Too bad you have so much trouble playing guide through Berlin this summer. I gave no man your address, but Frl. von Schilling (russian lady, Villa Luisisana) has it; - guess she won¡t make use of it though. - Eitels are coming to Berlin for 2 or 3 days next week and would like to see you.

My dear little baby!
To-day we had expected a letter or postal from you, but it did not come. Well, we do not worry about you, for you must be alive and well since you could address and mail Billy's letter to me. How can you let us know when your train will arrive here on Fridday: by postal or telegraph?
Before you leave Berlin, give your letter-carrier a

hurry, just five minutes before
dinner and must stop now.
Are both feeling all right.
With love, from mamma also,
your
Aennchen.
Please let us know when
you are coming, so that we
can order a room for you.

and are glad to hear that uncle Ernst

cough. But please go to a specialist anyway
and even if he says it is nothing
serious, tell him: "serious or not serious,
you want to be cured of that cough."
What is the difference whether it is only a

there and doesn't go away? Maybe you

does not agree with you; better ask the 
doctor about that. And take good care

Mahoney that book with a card from mamma, which I shall send you to-morrow and on which she will write a few words.
Now comes a new "Auftrag": mamma would like you to send her the large flat box from under your bed, which contains her black velvet cape. You will have to wrap the box up in some strong paper, probably, and then send it by an express or "packet" Co. who will call for it at your house, so that you need not lug it about yourself.
The letter you wrote to uncle Adolph was all right: he need not know that he is so very sick; that would only worry him.
